title: Papers and patents are becoming less disruptive over time - Nature

last_post.content:
I hadn't actually looked at the details of the #science is becoming less #disruptive paper (see here: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-022-05543-x), and only looked at it after reading Alex Usher's take on it (https://higheredstrategy.com/discovery-slowing/).

Now that I have, I gotta say: I think this paper tells us nothing about the #quality of science being done nowadays. Instead, it tells us much more about (1) the culture of #citations in science, and (2) the ease of finding and reading older papers.

Lindenmayer-systems are a kind of grammar, to describe and model the growth of plants. title: A Siemens S7-1500 Logic Controller Flaw Raises the Specter of Stuxnet

last_post.content: A vulnerability disclosed today in the ubiquitous Siemens S7-1500 PLC line allows any 1500 to sign firmware for any other 1500 ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ It's an issue in hardware so Siemens doesn't have a fix coming. They emphasize that the bug isn't remotely exploitable. It's not like there are any obvious examples of real world attacks that jumped the air gap to target S7 PLCs, right? https://www.wired.com/story/siemens-s7-1500-logic-controller-flaw/

title: Temporal context and latent state inference in the hippocampal splitter signal

last_post.content:
Hi all 😃​
Our latest #Review on #SplitterCells is now published in @eLife !!
I will probably write a real thread on it when I get a chance... for now:

link: https://elifesciences.org/articles/82357

why: some neurons in the #Hippocampus (and other brain regions) of #Rats (and other mammals) have the fascinating ability to discriminate not just different presents, but different past or future states or trajectories in the same current situation. They could be related to #EpisodicMemory or #DecisionMaking 🤔​They are called 'trajectory-dependent cells' or Splitter Cells. 🔀​ We tried to make sense of them!

what: Hippocampal Splitter cells do a lot of puzzling stuff. For example there's a lot of them even in tasks that do not require the Hippocampus to be solved. They spread asymmetrically on a linear track leading to a choice point - 'past' splitters around the start and 'future' splitters towards the choice point. #TimeCells cells can be splitter cells (but they're usually #PlaceCells). Splitter cells evolve with experience, or maybe it is performance, nobody really knows. ​⁉️​ ... and a lot more weird stuff

conclusion: Two different computational models, the temporal context model and the latent state model, each explain a subset of the properties of splitter cells... so perhaps the Hippocampus implements both! But more experiments are needed to disentangle them 😄​

now what: questions or comments? Please let us know!! ✍️​

#Neuroscience #Cognition #NeuroPaper

title: facebook.com/wix/posts/what-is...

last_post.content:
Ich weiß noch nicht warum, aber manche Infografiken (Sharebildchen würde besser passen), regen mich auf. Aktuell sind es die Todsünden als Plattformen vom Katapult Magazin.

Drei mögliche Erklärungen fallen mir ein.

1. Mein Humor ist inkompatibel.

2. Ich lese Botschaften heraus, denen ich widerspreche.
Das Konzept der Todsünden ist an sich Mist, wird aber durch solche Neu-Interpretationen weitergetragen: "Gefühle sind böse. Habt keine Gefühle, seid arbeitsam und tugendhaft.".
Darüber hinaus werden Plattformen und ihre Nutzer*innen auf einzelne Eigenschaften reduziert, was wiederum Stereotypen fördert. Wird man entspannt etwas auf Netflix schauen, nachdem man den Post gesehen hat oder sich denken, dass man das nicht sollte, weil dann ist man ja faul (Red.: Faulheit gibt es nicht.).

3. Schon zu oft gesehen.
Ältester Tweet dazu von 2011.
https://twitter.com/rondiggity/status/137584586241744896 Danach gab es zahlreiche weitere Variationen. Und zuvor wahrscheinlich auch. Auf anderen Plattformen ebenfalls.
2018 ist bereits eine ähnliches Sharebild herumgereicht worden. Laut Signatur als Werbung für wix https://www.facebook.com/wix/posts/what-is-your-digital-sin/10156160970575429/
